issue.title: Development setup notes: 'installing from git' link not working properly
issue.body:
The link reloads the entire page and doesn't even redirect to the required location
Instead it should just be '#installing-from-git'

issue.title: Run coala in travis with --ci flag
issue.body:
Currently, Travis is run in --non-interactive mode. Since we are testing in CI, therefore --ci flag should be used to maintain uniformity. (Note: --ci is an alias for --non-interactive)
difficulty/newcomer
area/ci

issue.title: Maximum time to expand globs
issue.body:
There should be a setting for max time to expand globs, and an error if glob expansion takes longer than the setting.
Default should be one minute.
See #5966 for background about why.
Low difficulty for only emitting an error if the max was exceeded.
Medium difficulty to also stop expanding the glob when the max is exceeded, i.e. for it to be a timeout.
As a follow up issue, to be created after this is completed, coala should stop processing only effected sections, and continue processing unaffected sections.  Thus is needs to determine which sections would be effected by the glob.

Same as #4992 , but now for 4.x

issue.title: cached-property dependency is unnecessarily high
issue.body:
I have tested with cached-property 1.3.0, and it worked fine.
openSUSE Tumbleweed only includes cached-property 1.3.0, and should be acceptable.
https://software.opensuse.org/package/python3-cached-property?search_term=python3-cached-property
We should also look to see if older versions are also passing our tests.

issue.title: Report debug messages during glob expansion
issue.body:
coala appears to hang whenever a glob takes a long time to expand.
This happens very frequently when it descends into node_modules/ .  There are other bugs about coala behaving better when descending a node_modules/, but typically nobody wants it to descend node_modules/, so this should be an error.
There should be regular debug messages during a glob expansion, including when they appear in files = .. and ignore = ...

issue.title: Add language definition for Solidity
issue.body: https://github.com/antlr/grammars-v4/tree/master/solidity

issue.title: Create a line length test helper
issue.body:
A line length test helper will take a chunk of source , and a regex, and verify the bear accepts source under the line length and rejects lines over the line length.
The max_line_length setting can be automatically determined by the lines in the source provided by the caller.  The bear should pass this test.
The regex is then used to increase the size of the source line lengths by 1 character, in accordance with the source language rules.
The helper confirms that the source was increased by 1 character only, and re-runs the bear, and expects it to fail.

issue.body:
Overview Description
Search bar at https://coala.io/#/languages doesn't produce any results while searching for any query
Steps to Reproduce

Go to https://coala.io/#/languages
Search for bears/languages in the search bar

Actual Results
Nothing happens
Expected Results
Should show relevant results
Reproducibility
Additional Information:
Please ping a maintainer at coala's Gitter channel and ask them to assign this to you

issue.title: verify_local_bear: Add base directory argument
issue.body:
Some linters expect to have some additional files in the base directory where it is invoked.
verify_local_bear needs an optional argument to supply this directory, and then change into that directory while running the bear.
coala_utils 's ContextManagers.change_directory may be useful for this.

issue.title: Language definition for HTML is broken
issue.body: A ' in the text will cause parsers to look for a closing '. e.g. Don't let work go to waste

issue.title: Missing attributes for CSS language definition
LocalBearTestHelper.check_results allow regex as message text
issue.body:
Sometimes the message text varies based on linter version, as we see at coala/coala-bears#2678,  or is incredibly long and not helpful to match the entire text.
It should be possible to specify only a regex to match the message text.

issue.title: Missing value for ignore empties it
issue.body:
[missing_value]
ignore = aaa,bbb
ignore += 

[next_section]

Expected behavior:
This should throw an error, the user should fix it.
Current behavior:
Nothing gets ignored.

issue.title: ShowPatchAction: Make patches better readable
issue.body:
Currently no context lines are displayed, which makes it very hard to grasp simple code relocations. E.g. coala proposed following patch (I added unified-diff-like markers because coala just colors added and deleted lines, it doesn't show + and -):
[----] /app/etc/test.json
[++++] /app/etc/test.json
[  18]+         "xray": {
[  19]+             "package": [
[  20]+                 "com.example.xray"
[  21]+             ],
[  22]+             "value": 33.33
[  23]+         },
[  23]-         },
[  24]-         "xray": {
[  25]-             "package": [
[  26]-                 "com.example.xray"
[  27]-             ],
[  28]-             "value": 33.33

I just relocated the xray entry, but it's really hard to see that (look at the line numbers). Esp. you have a problem to check where it is exactly located. You can only see the line numbers, open your editor, navigate to those lines, and check up if the position is correct and doesn't produce invalid JSON.
This is not acceptable and coala has to print better diffs here showing a few context lines like git does.

issue.title: pyyaml 3.x fails on Python 3.7-dev
issue.body:
Build error
https://travis-ci.org/jayvdb/coala/jobs/395717595

issue.title: Expand ruby language definition
issue.body:
The ruby language definition in coala is empty.
coala should have at least a basic language file for ruby.
There are quite a few concepts in Ruby which can not be correctly described using the limited coala language concepts, especially % string literals and balanced delimiters.

issue.title: Section: Set files to ignore list from another section
issue.body:
It is quite common to have two sections with opposite sets of files included.
e.g. one section might use line length = 80 and the other section uses 120
At the moment, to do this requires listing the same files twice.

issue.title: .coafile not showing the correct error
issue.body:
An earlier typo in .coafile which is being fixed by #5043 doesn't show the correct error message. Instead it shows an error based on the previous line
eg. if your .coafile has this
use_spaces = true
default_action: **: ApplyPatchAction

it will show
 Unable to convert parameter 'use_spaces' into type <class 'bool'>.

if your .coafile is
files = *.txt
default_action: **: ApplyPatchAction

It will show Unable to find that file/ No matching file
or if your .coafile is
bears = SpaceConsistencyBear
default_action: **: ApplyPatchAction

it will show
No bears matching 'SpaceConsistencyBear
default_action: **: ApplyPatchAction' were found. Make sure you have coala-bears installed or you have typed the name correctly.

Instead it should point out the error in the statement itself

issue.title: Modify tests for URLHeadBear dependents to support user-agent header
issue.body:
#2879 PR  adds a user-agent header to the request made by URLHeadBear. The HTTPSBearTest and InvalidLinkBearTest cause the build to fail as they depend on the URLHeadBear.
What to do:
Add user-agent header used by the URLHeadBear to the requests made by these tests.

issue.title: Bear proposal: package.json bear
issue.body: A linter for package.json files: https://github.com/tclindner/npm-package-json-lint

issue.title: Loosen pins based on openSUSE build 20190215
issue.body:
opensuse_tumbleweed_build_green_20190215.txt
Attached is a build log of https://build.opensuse.org/package/show/home:jayvdb:coala/python-coala-bears , while green.
Identify the linter versions used, where the bear tests pass, and update the bear requirements to allow these versions.
The tests should not need to be updated, as the tests are currently passing on opensuse build machines using those versions.
Where the tests need to be updated, maybe due to some difference between openSUSE and Ubuntu, they should be modified so that the old versions of the linter still would pass the tests.
Add notes here if there are any which are needing discussion, especially if the tests fail extensively.

issue.title: Add missing skips
issue.body:
Tests should skip if dependencies are missing.  Currently all python deps are pre-installed, but

we want to change that
in distro packaging, that isnt always feasible as some packages may not be possible/ready/compatible.

issue.title: Project Proposal: More Interactive CLIs
issue.body:
Currently, all the coala CLI interactions occur through numeric inputs which is very slow and cumbersome in most cases. This can be improved greatly by building more interactive CLIs using tools like PyInquirer. We have a lot of areas where the CLI can be improved.
For example we can use:

the checkbox question type for coala-quickstart.
the checkbox question type again when we run coala.

Apart from replacing number based inputs, we can:

add auto-complete in prompting for bears in both coala and coala-quickstart.
add a fuzzy finder like in git when we enter an invalid option to the CLI.

This could be a GSoC size project once all the potential areas of implementation are identified.
Note: If you're not familiar with using such CLIs, checkout:

npm/yarn
eslint CLI - eslint --init

issue.title: coala-antlr Enhancement
issue.body:
Particularly i will start by adding the grammars which will be asm8080,asm8086 which is intel based processors.For that language definitions for the same will be added in coala.Now the bears for them will be added as of now there are no bears which works for the microprocessors or microcontrollers.Similarly a grammar will be updated on upstream for PIC microcontrollers where a language definition will also be included in coala for the same.Henceforth the bears for the microcontroller and microprocessors will be supported by this project.Basically bears will be used to style the opcode like capitalization of special functions registers etc. which are used for ADC, sensors interfacing.
Apart from this i am planning to make a tree rewriting based on the above grammars generated trees it could be done using the generated template, if it is possible
"without having that functionality on the upstream antlr".

issue.title: Make coala a GitHub App

I guess coala would be much more popular if it can be made a GitHub App.
This means coala needs to be run as a web service, deployed somewhere like Heroku (but it's not totally free hmmm....)
GitMate + coala actually do the same thing, but that means developers need to learn both GitMate and coala, and GitMate requires admin access, which sounds a bit risky to developers (that's because GitMate has other functionalities, but coala does not need that high-level permission).

issue.title: Support TOML as another settings file format
issue.body:
According to https://github.com/toml-lang/toml
TOML aims to be a minimal configuration file format that's easy to read due to obvious semantics. TOML is designed to map unambiguously to a hash table. TOML should be easy to parse into data structures in a wide variety of languages.
TOML has widespread acceptance, documentation and robust parsers.
Also according to https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0518/, TOML is

Human-usable (unlike JSON ),
Flexible (unlike configparser),
Stems from a standard (unlike configparser)
Not overly complex (unlike YAML).

Also TOML has been recommended as the configuration file for software packages to specify their build dependencies.
 pyproject.toml is being used for this purpose. https://github.com/pypa/pip/blob/master/pyproject.toml
coala could provide TOML as a additional setting format.

By following a well known standard like TOML, we would reduce the learning curve involved.
When the current system gets complex, TOML will be a better choice than a custom INI.
It provides flexibility, consistency, backwards compatibility and stems from a standard all of which are drawbacks of configparser.

This proposal issue is about supporting a new config file like coafile.toml along with .coafile.
coala/coala#4609

issue.title: Create git-bug project
issue.body:
https://github.com/MichaelMure/git-bug cc @MichaelMure who has agreed to mentor.
Initial concept is bidirectional sync to GitHub issues with support for bridge impersonating multiple users, e.g. so corobo could be used to create issues as the person who used the bot (or maybe gitmate)
Another idea is GitLab issues support.
Another is a meta-git-bug for handling lots of projects, e.g. super repo with subtrees/submodules/etc of git-bug repos , or housing many GitHub sync'd repos of issue in a single git-bug repo
Ultimately this needs to be quite a broad project definition at this stage as many medium sized enhancements planned now might be completed before GSoC begins in 2019
Also worth investigating is git-appraise .

issue.title: corobo CI failing due to Pycodestyle Warning W605
issue.body:
In python 3.6, Unknown escapes consisting of \ and an ASCII letter in regular expressions will
cause an warning.In the upcoming python versions this would be treated as an error.
Owing to it pycodestyle have added this check for future Python versions.
Therefore Corobo's travis CI spits out the W606 warning for the following lines:
**** PycodestyleBear (W605) [Section: all.autopep8 | Severity: NORMAL] **** !    ! W605 invalid escape sequence '\(' labhub_test.py
**** PycodestyleBear (W605) [Section: all.autopep8 | Severity: NORMAL] **** !    ! W605 invalid escape sequence '\(' ban_test.py
The link of the build can be found below:
https://travis-ci.org/coala/corobo/builds/488152691

issue.title: django command logging levels
issue.body:
Django command interface has the following CLI arg
  -v {0,1,2,3}, --verbosity {0,1,2,3}
                        Verbosity level; 0=minimal output, 1=normal output,
                        2=verbose output, 3=very verbose output

issue.title: Add check for "www.github.com" and "www.gitlab.com"

The resource key in remote url can also have a value of www.github.com or www.gitlab.com.
Currently, it checks for github.com or gitlab.com due to which the command .ci/build.sh when executed in terminal raises the following Exception while running the app locally
File "/home/kvgarg/GSOC/Coala Open Source/community/community/urls.py", line 12, in <module>
    from gci.feeds import LatestTasksFeed as gci_tasks_rss
File "/home/kvgarg/GSOC/Coala Open Source/community/gci/feeds.py", line 10, in <module>

File "/home/kvgarg/GSOC/Coala Open Source/community/gci/feeds.py", line 12, in LatestTasksFeed
    link = get_deploy_url() + '/gci/tasks/rss.xml'
File "/home/kvgarg/GSOC/Coala Open Source/community/community/git.py", line 180, in get_deploy_url
    raise Exception('remote %s is not supported' % url)
TypeError: not all arguments converted during string formatting

This can be solved by putting an OR condition to check whether url.resource has a value of www.github.com or www.gitlab.com.

issue.title: Add status to issues tasks in tasks.yaml
issue.body:
When a task has max_instances: 1 and an issues URL , it can be annotated with an extra attribute to indicate the task status: available, claimed or completed.
Instance are exported as instances.yaml , and indicate whether the task is in progress or completed.
Completed issues are the easiest to work with.
In progress tasks are slightly more complicated because the publish instances are filtered to remove tasks still in early phases of the task lifecycle.  See https://github.com/coala/community/blob/master/gci/students.py#L84

issue.body:
Netlify forms can be used to let people 'become a developer' from their web browser.  It allows signing using GitHub, for authenticated collection of their username to be added to the org.  We could also add a field for the issue they want to be assigned to.
It is then easy for maintainers to invite them to the org after some rudimentary checks, or add a http://webtask.io which automatically invites them if they pass some basic automated checks to prevent abuse.

issue.body:
This issue is very similar to #299. Everything there holds true for this one, just that this one is for api.coala.io instead of docs.coala.io.
This would make a nice newcomer issue. Once one of them is solved, the person can follow the same process to solve the other one.
Overview Description
The coala header in https://api.coala.io/en/latest/ gets scaled only horizontally when viewed using mobile browsers leading to a distortion of the logo. It would be better if the consistency of the logo is maintained.
Steps to Reproduce
Open https://api.coala.io/en/latest/ in any mobile web browser (portrait mode)
Actual Results

Expected Results
If the image scales while preserving aspect ratio and is aligned to the center or to the left, the logo would remain round.

comments.bodyText:
Before the changes,

Context lines are now displayed.

The printing of the patch was handled by print_beautified_diff . This function took difflib.unified_diff as its input.  But difflib.unified_diff had n=3 which is the default number of context lines that will be supplied.
The print_beautified_diff took care of printing the affected lines but it did not print the normal context lines.

comments.bodyText: @sladyn98 Tests fail, before making a PR just run pytest if you've made changes, and make sure that the coverage is 100%.
Yeah thats what we wanted to check actually @Makman2 and I had foreseen this :( now we need to make some modifications.

Okay now what I meant with considering all cases is that the bear might really refer to a line/column that doesn't exist. While line 1 column 1 is a valid position in an empty file, the bear might still pass a bad range (due to a bug or similar). That case has to be differentiated, otherwise user will get heavily confused.
E.g. if we have a file with 100KB but the bear points us to a location at line infinity, that's out of range, and not an empty file^^

comments.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,85 @@
+Testing coala change on coala-bears
+===================================
+
+When large changes are made to the coala core, they should be tested
+on the coala-bears to confirm that they work as expected and don't
+break anything on the bears' side.
+
+There was an attempt to automate this through
+https://github.com/coala/coala/pull/4424 which used to depend upon docker
+image, but unfortunately the image breaks stuff for now.
+
+But we can still do it manually, by changing the coala dependency for the
+bears to be the one consisting of the changes made For which we need to create
+a new branch on coala-bears, edit the requirements and run it on CI.
+
+Set-up a new testing branch
+---------------------------
+
+Assuming we have already made changes to coala through a new branch, we can
+use the branch to install coala instead of master by editing requirements.txt
+file in coala-bears. So, lets set-up a new branch on coala-bears for these
+changes.
+
+If you have not already, clone your fork by running:
+
+::
+
+    $ git clone https://github.com/<your-username>/coala-bears
+
+Make sure that you replace <your-username> with your corresponding github
+username.
+
+Now, navigate to the directory where coala-bears is located.
+
+::
+
+    $ cd coala-bears
+
+Before making any change, switch to a new branch (other than master).
+
+::
+
+    $ git checkout -b new_test_branch
+
+.. note::
+    Never make any changes on your master branch.
+    See `Git Tutorial <https://coala.io/gitbasics>`_ for more info.
+
+Now you've done that, you are free to make changes.
+
+Change coala dependency in requirements.txt
+-------------------------------------------
+
+First thing we need is to change the coala dependency.
+
+Now assuming you have made changes to coala fork on branch <branch-name>, you
+can edit the coala dependency by changing the corresponding line to:
+
+::
+
+    git+https://github.com/<your-username>/coala@<branch-name>#egg=coala
+
+Set-up CI to run on your branch
+-------------------------------
+
+Since you need the tests to be ran on CI, set it up by modifying respective
+configuration files. You can have a look at our
+`CI Tutorial <https://api.coala.io/en/latest/Developers/Adding_CI.html>`_.
+for more info.
+
+For example, to run `travis-ci <https://travis-ci.org/>`_ on your
+branch you could modify .travis.yml file. At the end of the file, you'll find
+branch specification where you could white-list your branch name. So you should
+have the change as following:
+
+::
+
+    branches:
+      only:
+        - new_test_branch
+
+Simillarly, you can make changes to appveyor.yml file to run tests on AppveyorCI

+a new branch on coala-bears, update the coala requirement to point to our
+changes and run it on CI.
+
+Set up a new testing branch
+---------------------------
+
+Assuming we have already made changes to coala through a new branch, we can
+use this branch to install coala instead of master by editing requirements.txt
+in coala-bears. Let's set-up a new branch on coala-bears for these
+changes.
+
+If you have not already, clone your fork by running:
+
+::
+
+    $ git clone https://github.com/<your-username>/coala-bears
+
+Make sure that you replace <your-username> with your Github username.
+
+Now, navigate to the directory where coala-bears is located.
+
+::
+
+    $ cd coala-bears
+
+Before making any change, switch to a new branch.
+
+::
+
+    $ git checkout -b new_test_branch
+
+.. note::
+    Never make any changes on your master branch.
+    See `Git Tutorial <https://coala.io/gitbasics>`_ for more info.
+
+Now that you're on a new branch, you are free to make changes.
+
+Change coala dependency in requirements.txt
+-------------------------------------------
+
+First, we need to change the coala dependency.
+
+Now, assuming you have made changes to coala fork on branch <branch-name>, you
+can edit the coala dependency by changing the corresponding line to:
+
+::
+
+    git+https://github.com/<your-username>/coala@<branch-name>#egg=coala
+
+Apply changes on coala-bears
+----------------------------
+
+Since the current changes aren't used anywhere on the bears, you need to

.coafile:

default_actions: **: ApplyPatchAction

And why are we using a random UserAgent? Using a specific browser header like firefox/chrome would be much better.

comments.bodyText: @soumya-ranjan7 @li-boxuan Review this please

@li-boxuan
I checked locally by adding JSONFormatBear on two sections and checked the appropriate message displayed when the json_sort value is either true or false.
Then I moved on to writing test using LocalBearTestHelper.
I was using check_results for the test cases.
But I got a assertion error like this,
AssertionError: {'default': <coalib.results.Diff.Diff object at 0x7f7aec04acf8>} != {'default': <coalib.results.Diff.Diff object at 0x7f7aec05f9e8>}
This error is created by the check_results function inside LocalBearTestHelper.py .
It's comapring this whole string. But It should be comparing the Diff object's attribute values. This will always be false since the memory location will be always different.
In our codebase, the places where check_results is used was always used if the Diff object is None.
But here we are checking the message when the Diff is not None.
This type of test case is not tested previously. And check_results doesn't seem appropriate for this.
So what should I do in this case ?
Updated:
Approaches we can proceed with:
Creating a custom string reprsentation of diff object will resolve this.
Or defining a object.__eq__(self, other) function in coali.results.Diff would also work.

@naveentvelu check_results should work. Compare the strings from both of the Result objects yourself. (See the length difference, assert wherever required to find out the difference between the two). You  should be able to get your mistake, if not then post the entire pytest error on gitter.

@abhishalya
The check_results will not work because, we have a diff object which is not None. So when you compare two of them their ids get compared rather than their attributes.
If you see the above assertion error,
It is because of diffs(one of the attributes of 'result' class) which belongs to <class 'dict'>. This has a key-value pair filename : <class 'coalib.results.Diff.Diff'>.
In the current implementation of check_results, this key-value pair is directly being compared.This causes the assertion error.

See the length difference, assert wherever required to find out the difference between the two.

This is not needed here because there will always be mismatch in the id's of class objects even if they have the same attribute with same values.

@abhishalya @li-boxuan
Finally one of the approaches work, I added a def__repr__(self): function in Diff class. And It solved the above assertion error.
Should I create a issue along with PR for modifying the Diff class?
It's in coala/coala repo. https://github.com/coala/coala/blob/master/coalib/results/Diff.py

Then I moved on to writing test using LocalBearTestHelper.
I was using check_results for the test cases.
But I got a assertion error like this ...

Post your code snippet, or just push with your unfinished code, so that people have a better understanding of your problem or find bugs with your code if there is any.

Then I moved on to writing test using LocalBearTestHelper.
I was using check_results for the test cases.
But I got a assertion error like this ...

Post your code snippet, or just push with your unfinished code, so that people have a better understanding of your problem or find bugs with your code if there is an

I got it right now. The mistake was on my side. I passed the wrong expected diff value. Sorry @li-boxuan @abhishalya

issue.title: reSTLintBear.py: Change rst_lint version
issue.body:
This adds support for Sphinx prolog and epilog and other new
features by changing restructuredtext-lint version from '1.0.0'
to '1.0' in the files reSTLintBear.py, bear-requirements.txt
and bear-requirements.yaml. This is done by ensuring that

issue.title: mentors.html: Change mentor page year dynamically
issue.body:
Have the year on the GSoC mentor page change dynamically
based on the current month. If it's past September, the page
will show the next year, otherwise it will show the current year.
Closes #706

comments.bodyText:
I prefer reading the number from 
  
    
      projects/_config.yml
    
    
         Line 9
      in
      ca8a58f
    
    
    
    

        
          
           gsoc_switch_month: 6
Hi @li-boxuan . Not entirely sure how we can go about injecting this variable into the angularjs script. Do you have anything in mind?
I could add frontmatter to the file app.js and use the variable as var gsocSwitchMonth = {{ site.gsoc_switch_month }}. Does this look like a good enough solution to you?
Hi @li-boxuan Made the desired changes.
Done in the new commit.
why are these being added?
@jayvdb This is the frontmatter needed by jekyll to interpolate a file. Without this we cannot read the value gsocSwitchMonth from the _config.yml file as suggested by @li-boxuan.

To avoid this @aedorado you can pass the value to function getGsocYear() from html page itself.
Doing so, will omit those two new lines containing hyphen
@li-boxuan Please review the PR.
Also, rebase needed ;-)

issue.title: app.js: Exclude mentors on disabled projects
issue.body:
Closes #707

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review
review it (check https://coala.io/reviewing for more info)
if you are sure that it needs work, use cobot mark wip <URL> to get it out
of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!

issue.title: app.js: Sort projects acc. to status in scope
issue.body:
The commit sorts the projectsList itself in the JavaScript file
using orderBy filter and set the sorted array globally, which
omits the use of orderBy filter in projects.html file
Fixes #711

pass on every single commit!

comments.bodyText: not well-designed content could be changed to poorly designed content for clarity
comments.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,10 @@
+---
+question: "What is a cEP and why it is so important to do analysis pre-gsoc and design as early as possible, to be finalized in the cEP?"
+---
+A **cEP(coala Enhancement Proposal)** is a proposal proposed to the coala community discussing the new major features that the contributor is intended to implement during GSoC.
+
+**cEP's** are designed before implementation. Implementing major features usually happens from a technical perspective and may lead to not well-designed content - developer and user wise. This can essentially save a lot of coding work when big features are written which are oftentimes not well enough designed initially. This also makes sure that major features are properly documented.

comments.bodyText: creating projects -> created projects and expanding on -> expanded on in order to preserve parallel structure from contributed to
comments.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,10 @@
+---
+question: "What is a cEP and why it is so important to do analysis pre-gsoc and design as early as possible, to be finalized in the cEP?"
+---
+A **cEP(coala Enhancement Proposal)** is a proposal proposed to the coala community discussing the new major features that the contributor is intended to implement during GSoC.
+
+**cEP's** are designed before implementation. Implementing major features usually happens from a technical perspective and may lead to not well-designed content - developer and user wise. This can essentially save a lot of coding work when big features are written which are oftentimes not well enough designed initially. This also makes sure that major features are properly documented.
+
+Anyone planning to do GSoC with coala should be starting to write detailed project ideas in our [projects](https://github.com/coala/projects) repository. Experience tells us that the best GSoC students are the ones who heavily contributed to the project ideas website, creating projects from the issues, and expanding on existing ***.md*** files. And generally learning how to express complex technical ideas in the markup. If you can't explain your idea, and how you will achieve it, we probably don't want to mentor you doing that undefined project.

issue.title: Add result reporter tool project
issue.body:
Closes #555

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review
review it (check https://coala.io/reviewing for more info)
if you are sure that it needs work, use cobot mark wip <URL> to get it out
of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!

comments.bodyText: It might also provide should be changed to Providing linters with ...
comments.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,86 @@
+---
+collaborating_projects:
+  - coala
+desc: "Implement a result reporter tool that converts linter/bear results
+into various formats"
+difficulty: medium
+initiatives:
+  - GSoC
+issues:
+  - "https://github.com/coala/projects/issues/555"
+  - "https://github.com/coala/coala/issues/2757"
+  - "https://github.com/coala/coala/issues/5910"
+  - "https://gitlab.com/coala/coala-json/issues/3"
+markdown: result-reporter-tool.md
+mentors:
+  - li-boxuan
+name: "Result Reporter Tool"
+requirements:
+  - "The applicant should have at least one non-trivial patch merged to
+    coala or coala-bears."
+  - "The applicant should be familiar with Python."
+  - "Familiarity with continuous integration tools (e.g. Jenkins) is a plus."
+tags:
+  - Core
+  - Linter
+  - CI
+---
+
+Apart from common CLI output, coala provides json format output. However, there
+are other formats which are useful for reporting tests and failures, but coala
+does not support at the moment.
+
+This is not only for coala, result format inconsistencies has been a problem for
+a long time. Converting the static analysis results into a test results format
+has been done a few times, such as early PEP8 plugins to Jenkins. The mapping
+isn't exact, but the benefits of using the test result format is tight
+integration with various systems.
+
+Most commonly used is JUnit format. CircleCI can accept
+[this format](https://circleci.com/docs/2.0/collect-test-data). AppVeyor can
+receive test results in [XML format](https://www.appveyor.com/docs/running-tests/#uploading-xml-test-results).
+Other formats include [TAP](https://testanything.org/),
+[Clover](http://openclover.org/doc/manual/latest/ant--clover-report.html),
+There are some systems, such as Phabricator, which have a
+[custom format](https://github.com/facebook/infer/issues/673) they expect.
+
+The applicant is welcomed to propose additional ideas around format topic, to
+improve coala workflow, continuous integration workflow or linters workflow.
+For example, pulling the coala results from CI could be a way to inform newbies
+of the style problems with their PRs. Pushing the unit test results as XML to
+the CI (using combination XML files if necessary). It might also provide

issue.title: Fix w605
issue.body:
Reviewers Checklist

 Appropriate logging is done.
 Appropriate error responses.
 Handle every possible exception.
 Make sure there is a docstring in the command functions. Hint: Lookout for
botcmd and re_botcmd decorators.
 See that 100% coverage is there.
 See to it that mocking is not done where it is not necessary.

comments.bodyText: Make this(30) line //(, just to make the trident symmetric?
Yeah this could be done as well , but is it really required :P
Yes, otherwise it'll look odd.

Actually it has to be just here. The double escape will in the chat print as a single one, so making below a double // would then look weird in the output. You could probably just prepend r to the string to make it a raw string so it keeps symmetric in code and in output.
See previous comment: This makes output "asymmetric".
Can't we just fix to the latest dev-version inside test-requirements.txt? Then we don't introduce silent breakages by updates in the coala and coala-bears breakages without an explicit upgrade here^^

CLAIMED or COMPLETED to those tasks which have max_instances=1
and an issues URL. Based upon these COMPLETED tasks, the instances
are being filtered out during cleansing.
Closes #66

@KVGarg

I have changed the commit message from web only, by choosing edit message option, instead of changing through git terminal

You might have misinterpreted the heading of the PR with the commit message. In fact, you cannot change the commit message via Github. The reason being the hash for every Git commit is also calculated based on the commit message. When you change the commit message, you change the commit hash. If you want to push that commit, you have to force that push . Which is not possible via Github. In short - You cannot change the commit message using the Github Interface.
Please use git commit --amend in your terminal to update your message.

The commit adds instructions for running coala-html on a local system.
Closes #135

comments.bodyText:
This command is Ubuntu specific. Either

Provide install commands for other major distros(Fedora, Arch, OpenSuse etc) or
Provide a link to Official Installation Documentation of NodeJS, so that users not on Ubuntu can seamlessly install NodeJS
comments.diffHunk:

 BUILD & DEVELOPMENT
 -------------------
 
-Run ``python3 setup.py install``
+1. Clone the *coala-html* repository
 
-Note: You need to have bower installed before you may install the python packages.
+::
+
+  $ git clone https://github.com/coala/coala-html.git
+
+2. Install latest version of **Node.js**
+
+- *Configure Node.js PPA*
+
+::
+
+    $ sudo apt-get install curl python-software-properties
+    $ curl -sL https://deb.nodesource.com/setup_11.x | sudo bash -
+
+- *Install Node.js and npm*
+
+::
+
+  $ sudo apt-get install nodejs

+  <https://nodejs.org/>`__.
+
+::
+
+    $ node -v
+    v11.6.0
+
+    $ npm -v
+    6.5.0
+
+3. Install **bower** to build static web pages
+
+::
+
+    $ sudo npm install -g bower
+
+4. Change the directory to *coala-html* and run following command to install dependencies
+
+::
+
+    $ python setup.py install
+
+5. Install **coala-bears**
+
+::
+
+    $ pip install coala-bears
+
+6. Allow permissions to **root user** to install node packages
+
+::
+
+    $ sudo chown -R $USER:$GROUP ~/.npm
+    $ sudo chown -R $USER:$GROUP ~/.config
+    $ sudo chown -R $USER:$GROUP ~/.cache/bower/registry/registry.bower.io/lookup/
+    $ sudo chown -R $USER:$GROUP ~/.cache/bower/packages
+
+7. Run **coala-html** to display results from *coala-json*
+
+::
+
+$ coala-html --dir ..\Tests
+
+For more usage details, refer to the usage_ section.

-Note: You need to have bower installed before you may install the python packages.
+::
+
+  $ git clone https://github.com/coala/coala-html.git
+
+2. Install latest version of **Node.js**
+
+- *Configure Node.js PPA*
+
+::
+
+    $ sudo apt-get install curl python-software-properties
+    $ curl -sL https://deb.nodesource.com/setup_11.x | sudo bash -
+
+- *Install Node.js and npm*
+
+::
+
+  $ sudo apt-get install nodejs
+
+- *Check Node.js and npm version*
+
+  You can find more details about current version on node.js `official website
+  <https://nodejs.org/>`__.
+
+::
+
+    $ node -v
+    v11.6.0
+
+    $ npm -v
+    6.5.0
+
+3. Install **bower** to build static web pages
+
+::
+
+    $ sudo npm install -g bower
+
+4. Change the directory to *coala-html* and run following command to install dependencies
+
+::
+
+    $ python setup.py install
+
+5. Install **coala-bears**
+
+::
+
+    $ pip install coala-bears
+
+6. Allow permissions to **root user** to install node packages
+
+::
+
+    $ sudo chown -R $USER:$GROUP ~/.npm
+    $ sudo chown -R $USER:$GROUP ~/.config
+    $ sudo chown -R $USER:$GROUP ~/.cache/bower/registry/registry.bower.io/lookup/
+    $ sudo chown -R $USER:$GROUP ~/.cache/bower/packages
+
+7. Run **coala-html** to display results from *coala-json*
+
+::
+
+$ coala-html --dir ..\Tests

comments.bodyText: Installing node modules with the -g flag installs them globally under /usr/lib and if the flag is not specified it is installed in the current folder. You need to find the exact command that installs the packages and maybe fix that, because, giving root permissions inside /home/ is never advised.

issue.body:
Closes #148

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review
review it (check https://coala.io/reviewing for more info)
if you are sure that it needs work, use cobot mark wip <URL> to get it out
of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!
